mentions.context: 3D-iVFM is able to recover three-component velocity vector fields in a full intraventricular volume by using a clinical echocardiographic triplane mode.
3D-iVFM produced vorticity profiles consistent with those given by CFD (ground-truth).

The iVFM-derived flow structures were consistent with those of the CFD ground-truth.
The iVFM that we introduced in this work is a three-dimensional upgrade of the previous 2D version (Vixège et al 2021b).

The EchoPAC software gives access to the series of three planes that contain both Doppler velocities and 8 bit B-mode images in the spherical coordinate system q j r, , { } related to the cardiac phased array (figure 3).
Using TensorFlow, they regularized the velocity fields by imposing mechanical constraints and endocardial boundary conditions.
The 3D-iVFM problem was written in the spherical (radial, polar, azimuthal) coordinate system associated to the six half-planes produced by the triplane mode.

The 3D-iVFM approach allows the echographer to estimate the 3D intraventricular flow from three color-Doppler planes, by using a minimization problem constrained by hemodynamic properties (mass conservation in the cardiac cavity, and free-slip boundary conditions on the endocardium).
The 3D-iVFM method starts with the three color Doppler planes given by the triplane mode (figure 2).
The 3D-iVFM was derived using a 3rd-order tensor formalism.
The 3D-iVFM velocimetric method uses a clinical triplane mode, which provides three long-axis planes (i.e. six azimuthal half-planes, figures 2 and 4).
The 3D-iVFM technique reconstructed the radial components with accuracy ( = r 0.99) since the input information from color Doppler is essentially radial.
The 3D-iVFM technique enabled the reconstruction of intraventricular flows in selected patients after a routine echocardiographic examination.
The 3D-iVFM problem has essentially two unknowns, which are the polar and azimuthal angular components of the velocities.
The 3D-iVFM could be applicable in a clinical setting since it uses a standard apical echocardiographic window and fast algorithms.
The 3D-iVFM is compatible with standard echocardiographic examination and is not timeconsuming.
To make the iVFM technique unsupervised, we selected the smoothing parameter automatically through the L-curve method (Hansen 2000).
The rate of iVFM volumes is similar to that of 4D MRI velocimetry.

Inspired by 2D iVFM, Grønli et al reconstructed 3D intraventricular flow from Doppler volumes with an optimization method that aimed to conserve the mass (continuity equation) and momentum (Navier-Stokes equations).
The goal of 3D-iVFM, however, is to deduce global biomarkers that describes the intraventricular flow.
We validated 3D-iVFM in silico in a patient-specific CFD (computational fluid dynamics) model of cardiac flow and tested its clinical feasibility in vivo in patients and in one volunteer.

Validating the 3D-iVFM algorithm required full-volume three-component ground-truth velocity fields of the intraventricular blood flow.
We extended the 2D-iVFM algorithm proposed by Assi et al (2017) and added physics-based equality constraints to obtain a hemodynamically valid estimate (Vixège et al 2021b).
The objective of 3D-iVFM (3D-intraventricular Vector Flow Mapping) is to recover full-volume threecomponent velocity fields, in the left ventricular cavity, by using triplane color Doppler.

The objective of 3D-iVFM is to deduce the radial, polar, and azimuthal velocity components [ q j v r, , , r ( ) q j q v r, , , ( ) and q j j v r, , ( )] in the full left ventricular volume, from the Doppler velocities (u D ) of the three planes.

As illustrated by figures 6, 3D-iVFM enabled the reconstruction of full-volume three-component intraventricular velocity fields from three color-Doppler long-axis planes (triplane color Doppler).
The vortex volumes derived from iVFM agreed with those measured in the CFD model but contained some inconsistencies (figure 9).
In this paper, we introduce a 3D iVFM technique based on triplane Doppler-echo, which generalizes the 2D iVFM developed by Assi et al (2017) and Vixège et al (2021b).
The spherical 3D grid used for 3D-iVFM has constant radial, polar, and azimuthal steps (h , r q h , and j h ).
As we did for the 2D-iVFM, the 3D-iVFM was validated using an intracardiac CFD model.

Our results tend to indicate that 3D-iVFM could provide full-volume echocardiographic information on left intraventricular hemodynamics from the clinical modality of triplane color Doppler.

In the following, we describe the 3D-iVFM method and its numerical formulation, its validation using a patient-specific CFD (computational fluid dynamics) model, and its clinical applicability through in vivo examples.
Intraventricular vector flow mapping (iVFM) is a velocimetric technique for retrieving twodimensional velocity vector fields of blood flow in the left ventricular cavity.
In this study, we established that 3D-iVFM is feasible in patients.
) is a column vector that contains the iVFM solution of the minimization problem.
We tested the clinical feasibility of 3D-iVFM prospectively, during a routine echocardiographic examination, in one healthy volunteer and in three patients selected on the basis of image quality.
We have introduced an updated Doppler-based iVFM algorithm for recovering three-component full-volume intraventricular blood flows.
We compared the mean vortex volumes (CFD versus iVFM) over diastole.

We finally computed the full-volume three-component intraventricular velocity fields with the 3D-iVFM method.
The errors on the polar components were close to those observed with the recent version of the 2D-iVFM (Vixège et al 2021b), ranging between 2% and 10%.

More importantly, the global vorticity was determined accurately, which tends to show that the 3D-iVFM could be used for physiological purposes to characterize the intracavitary left ventricular flows.

To obtain a three-dimensional outlook of the left intraventricular flow, we hypothesized that our 2D iVFM algorithm (Assi et al 2017, Vixège et al 2021b) could be generalized to 3D by using the triplane mode available on clinical ultrasound scanners.
After writing the velocity fields with B-splines, the problem was solved using the opensource package TensorFlow (Grønli et al 2018).

In both in silico and in vivo investigations, the dynamics of the intraventricular vortex that forms during diastole was deciphered by 3D-iVFM.
We used a patient-specific CFD (computational fluid dynamics) model (Chnafa et al 2014(Chnafa et al , 2016)), as for the latest versions of 2D-iVFM (Assi et al 2017, Vixège et al 2021b).

The time for ultrasound acquisition (<20 s) and 3D velocity calculation (<20 s per volume), was well below that of 4D flow CMR, even though we used a homemade MATLAB code.

We chose the triplane mode (rather than volume Doppler) because (1) the ultrasound data before scan-conversion are available (figure 2) through the workstation EchoPAC (GE Healthcare), and (2) the temporal resolution is higher.

To overcome this limitation, several ultrasound imaging techniques have been developed for a 2D vector depiction of the intracardiac flow, such as echo-PIV (echographic particle image velocimetry) by contrast-enhanced echocardiography (Kheradvar et al 2010, Chen et al 2021), blood speckle tracking (Fadnes et al 2014, Daae et al 2021), or iVFM (intraventricular vector flow mapping) (Garcia et al 2010, Assi et al 2017).
